subject: Home & DIY
title: Why Wood Is Stronger Along the Grain
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Why Wood Is Stronger Along the Grain.

hook.text: Try snapping a stick lengthwiseâ€”nearly impossible. Now break it acrossâ€”it snaps easily. The difference is grain.

buildup.text: Wood is long cellulose fibers bundled together, running the trunk's length. They act like millions of parallel ropes.

discovery.text: Along the grain, force must snap millions of fibers at once. Across it, force just separates them like straws.

twist.text: Floor joists sit on edge (tall side up) so the grain runs lengthwise, resisting the bending force of people above.

climax.text: Plywood defeats this flaw by alternating grain direction in layers. Each layer reinforces the others in every axis.

punchline.text: Millions of tiny ropes make wood an engineering marvel.

quiz.question: Why is wood much stronger along the grain than across it?
options: Cellulose fibers run parallel, requiring massive force to break them all at once
Sap channels along the grain harden into reinforcing tubes
The bark compresses the outer fibers, strengthening the length
